node.title: If it is possible to develop a two-phase flow code like RELAP5

node.bodyText:
Definitely possible but it's a lot of work
@joshuahansel for a more elaborate answer

It's definitely possible, so long as you have the funding and resources to develop a two-phase code. As you suggested, RELAP-7 does the same thing but with the 7-equation model. Architecturally, you'd just follow the structure of THM or RELAP-7. If you have specific questions about how we've done things, we can answer those.
For Water97, you may need to implement more interfaces depending on your formulation and what lookups you need.
@SomnusYu can you please give us some background on your project? Is this a classic 3 year grant for PhD research?

Yes, it's my PHD project, and I have developed it for two years. These days I meet a lot of problems, so I am not sure it is possible to finish it.

node.title: Unable to get into "base" environment
node.bodyText:
I have successfully installed Mambaforge in my home directory and exported the path so it can be used.
When I run "mamba init" it initializes, and asks to close and reopen my current shell.
When I reopen my shell, I AM NOT GETTING INTO THE BASE ENVIRONMENT. I DO NOT SEE MY PROMPT PREFIXED WITH (BASE).  I am stuck in the loop since forever.

Hello
Which os/platform is this?
Open the .bashrc / profile (depending on the platform) and look for the prompt that starts mamba on console startup. is it there?
Guillaume

I have macOS.
My .bash_profile reads the following:

are you using zsh for the shell by any chance? if so the .bash_profile is completely ignored.
You ll have to modify the .zshprofile or stop using zsh (and use bash instead)
That worked! Thank you so much.

Another fix would be to run (something only recently discovered):
mamba init --all
that s genius. Making a PR to change our instructions rn

node.title: Artificial Driving force for flat grain boundary migration
node.bodyText: Hello, I am trying to study the interaction of grain boundaries with the spherical particles. For which I want a flat grain in a 3D space to migrate from one side of the box to other. But the driving force in grain growth is defined only by the curvature of the grain boundary. Is there a way to add artificial driving force in moose?

node.title: Resultant of Passing a Vector and the _grad Operator
node.bodyText:
Hello,
If I pass a row vector in a custom AuxKernek using this command:
  _direction(getParam<RealVectorValue>("direction"))
and then return
_direction * _grad_coupled_n[_qp] 
will this be a scalar?
Another related question, in the AuxKernel if the row vector above is called row_vector, is this passed as direction = '[1 0 0]' for the x-direction?
Thank you!

Hello
What is the type of _grad_coupled_n ? This is from your kernel right? I have not seen it in the moose base clases.
If it s a RealVectorValue / a VariableGradient then yes. * is the dot-product for 'vectors' (of size 2/3, RealVectorValue)
If you want to specify a vector in the input, 1 0 0 would be the X-direction indeed, you dont need to try to pass it vertically like
row_vector = '1
                         0
                         0'

(not like above)

OK this works thanks, _grad_coupled_n should have been pasted as  _grad_coupled_V and what really helped too was I found this AuxKernel VectorVariableMagnitudeAux and now my MOOSE test cases match my hand calculations for integrating current density to obtain current.

Yep

node.title: Variable, Material, Element Types
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am writing a research paper about a simulation I created using MOOSE and I need help with some details.
I know the variables are first order Lagrange by default and that is what I am using.
However, I am not sure what type the material properties are by default. I am using ADMaterialProperty Real. Are these first order monomial by default?
Also, I am using GeneratedMeshGenerator to create a 3D mesh. In the documentation, I see that the default elem_type is linear for the requested dimension but I am still unsure of what that means. What type of element is default for 3D?
Lastly, what is the preferred way of citing MOOSE for a publication?
Thank you,
Cameron

Hello
By default material properties are computed at quadrature points. they are not a particular finite element family, they dont require a projection onto shape functions.
However, when we output them to exodus, we project them on a constant monomial basis.
Default is Hex8 element in 3D. Second order (quadratic) element would be Hex20.
The preferred way of citing MOOSE is to follow the instructions there (and cite the 2.0 paper)
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/citing.html
Guillaume
Thank you!

node.title: use boost special functions in Function object definition
node.bodyText:
Hi all, I would like to use expint function in boost/math/special_functions/expint.hpp, after include the header file in the Function object:
#include <boost/math/special_functions/expint.hpp>
It throws out the file-not-found error:
/Users/andyz/projects/farms/src/functions/cdbm/InitialStressXYPressure.C:4:10: fatal error: 'boost/math/special_functions/expint.hpp' file not found
#include <boost/math/special_functions/expint.hpp>
         ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
1 error generated.

As I searched in the MOOSE source code, there are cases including boost special functions, so I wonder what I missed here, thanks!

If you look at the uses of boost special functions in MOOSE, they are guarded with
#ifdef LIBMESH_HAVE_EXTERNAL_BOOST

libMesh does have some boost headers. However, it does not have them all. In particular it does not have expint.hpp. So you would need to configure libMesh pointing to an external boost that has that header in order to be able to use it.
@roystgnr why do we have an "incomplete" boost?

So I wonder if there is still a way to directly add expint function in MOOSE without too much complexity, what I currently do is to compute the expression contains expint ouside MOOSE using Python and read the time series data file into MOOSE using PiecewiseMultilinear.
if it s just for your app / branch you can add a contrib then modify the Makefile
Hi @GiudGiud, could you elaborate more? I'm not familiar with the modifications I should do, thanks!

Complete boost is so huge (I just downloaded a tarball that expands to 900MB, 50x the subset we have) that boost itself includes bcp, a tool for creating incomplete subsets of boost.
Originally the libMesh logs claim Ben grabbed a subset of boost because we wanted shared_ptr and C++11 wasn't out yet.  Later we started optionally using their pool allocator ... and I'm not sure what else.  The ability to configure --with-boost=/some/external/boost is the recommended way to use arbitrary parts of boost.

ah me neither.
But you should be able to place a header from an external library into a contrib folder in your app, then in the Makefile add some logic so that it gets include in the include list

node.title: computeQpStrain Q-points values

node.bodyText: @cbolisetti @somu15 it looks like you guys have touched this class. Do you have any comment on @andrey1887's question?

@andrey1887 yes, that is correct. The beam implementation in MOOSE assumes only one qp in the beam. Typically, in structural analysis codes, you would need a pretty coarse mesh for modeling beam elements. But in MOOSE, I recommend that you use a finer mesh.

@andrey1887 yes that is correct. The elements have multiple qps but the rotation and strains are assumed to be constant through out the element. This is a reasonable assumption for small elements. The multiple quadrature points allow for spatially varying Young's modulus and cross sectional properties (area, I, shear coefficient, etc.).
Thank you @cbolisetti .
